articles.headline: U.S. Debates Fate of CIT, a Small-Business Lender
articles.snippet: The White House is considering whether to draw a line in the sand on banks “too big to fail,” and may start with CIT.
articles.abstract: The White House is considering whether to draw a line in the sand on banks “too big to fail,” and may start with CIT.
articles.lead_paragraph: The CIT Group is one of the nation’s biggest lenders to small businesses. But a debate is swirling in Washington over whether it is large enough  or important enough  to save.
articles.byline: By Julie Creswell and Stephen Labaton

articles.headline: Sotomayor Vows ‘Fidelity to the Law’ as Hearings Start
articles.snippet: Judge Sonia Sotomayor spoke about how her journey from public housing in the Bronx to the federal bench has shaped her judicial philosophy.
articles.abstract: Judge Sonia Sotomayor spoke about how her journey from public housing in the Bronx to the federal bench has shaped her judicial philosophy.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Judge Sonia Sotomayor opened her case for confirmation to the Supreme Court on Monday by assuring senators that she believes a judge’s job “is not to make law” but “to apply the law,” as the two parties used her nomination to debate the role of the judiciary.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Neil A. Lewis

articles.headline: Airlines, Already Suffering, Brace for More Woes
articles.snippet: Cuts in routes and workers may help weather the slump, but if conditions worsen, some carriers may not survive.
articles.abstract: Cuts in routes and workers may help weather the slump, but if conditions worsen, some carriers may not survive.
articles.lead_paragraph: The airline industry is in the midst of one of its most wrenching summers ever. And the fall and winter may be even worse  unless people start to fly again.
articles.byline: By Michelle Higgins and Gerry Shih

articles.headline: Obama’s Chief Auto Adviser Steps Down
articles.snippet: Steven Rattner, who has faced questions about his firm’s role in a pension scandal, will be succeeded by Ron Bloom.
articles.abstract: Steven Rattner, who has faced questions about his firm’s role in a pension scandal, will be succeeded by Ron Bloom.
articles.lead_paragraph: Steven Rattner is quitting his post as President Obama’s chief adviser on the troubled automobile industry at a time when an investigation into his former Wall Street firm’s role in a scandal involving public pension funds has intensified.
articles.byline: By David Stout and Michael J. de la Merced

articles.headline: C.I.A. Had Plan to Assassinate Qaeda Leaders
articles.snippet: The program was designed after the Sept. 11 attacks, but the plans were never carried out before Leon E. Panetta, the C.I.A. director, canceled it last month.
articles.abstract: The program was designed after the Sept. 11 attacks, but the plans were never carried out before Leon E. Panetta, the C.I.A. director, canceled it last month.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Since 2001, the Central Intelligence Agency has developed plans to dispatch small teams overseas to kill senior Qaeda terrorists, according to current and former government officials.
articles.byline: By Mark Mazzetti and Scott Shane

articles.headline: China Builds High Wall to Guard Energy Industry
articles.snippet: When U.S. energy and commerce officials arrive in Beijing on Tuesday, they will confront policies that protect China’s solar panel and wind farm industries.
articles.abstract: When U.S. energy and commerce officials arrive in Beijing on Tuesday, they will confront policies that protect China’s solar panel and wind farm industries.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING  When the United States’ top energy and commerce officials arrive in China on Tuesday, they will land in the middle of a building storm over China’s protectionist tactics to become the world’s leader in renewable energy.

articles.headline: Bing Delivers Credibility to Microsoft
articles.snippet: The once-dubious prospect that Microsoft could shake up the search business has become just a bit more likely.
articles.abstract: The once-dubious prospect that Microsoft could shake up the search business has become just a bit more likely.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO  In late May, Microsoft unveiled Bing, its new Internet search engine, in front of an audience of skeptics: technology executives and other digerati who had gathered near San Diego for an industry conference.

articles.headline: Exxon to Invest Millions to Make Fuel From Algae
articles.snippet: The program is a joint venture with a biotech company founded by the genomics pioneer J. Craig Venter.
articles.abstract: The program is a joint venture with a biotech company founded by the genomics pioneer J. Craig Venter.
articles.lead_paragraph: The oil giant Exxon Mobil, whose chief executive once mocked alternative energy by referring to ethanol as “moonshine,” is about to venture into biofuels.

articles.headline: Illnesses Afflict Homes With a Criminal Past
articles.snippet: With meth lab seizures rising, attention is being focused on contamination that can cause various health issues.
articles.abstract: With meth lab seizures rising, attention is being focused on contamination that can cause various health issues.
articles.lead_paragraph: WINCHESTER, Tenn.  The spacious home where the newly wed Rhonda and Jason Holt began their family in 2005 was plagued by mysterious illnesses. The Holts’ three babies were ghostlike and listless, with breathing problems that called for respirators, repeated trips to the emergency room and, for the middle child, Anna, the heaviest dose of steroids a toddler can take.
articles.byline: By Shaila Dewan and Robbie Brown

articles.headline: Iraq Suffers as the Euphrates River Dwindles
articles.snippet: The river is drying up as a result of the water policies of Iraq’s neighbors, a drought and years of misuse by Iraq.
articles.abstract: The river is drying up as a result of the water policies of Iraq’s neighbors, a drought and years of misuse by Iraq.
articles.lead_paragraph: JUBAISH, Iraq  Throughout the marshes, the reed gatherers, standing on land they once floated over, cry out to visitors in a passing boat.

articles.headline: With Big Profit, Goldman Sees Big Payday Ahead
articles.snippet: The bank posted the richest quarterly profit in its 140-year history and announced its plans to pay huge bonuses this year.
articles.abstract: The bank posted the richest quarterly profit in its 140-year history and announced its plans to pay huge bonuses this year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even on Wall Street, the land of six- and seven-figure incomes, jaws dropped at the news on Tuesday: After all that federal aid, a resurgent Goldman Sachs is on course to dole out bonuses that could rival the record paydays of the heady bull-market years.

articles.headline: Republicans Press Judge About Bias
articles.snippet: Judge Sonia Sotomayor insisted in the face of skeptical questioning from Republicans that she would never allow personal bias to influence her rulings.
articles.abstract: Judge Sonia Sotomayor insisted in the face of skeptical questioning from Republicans that she would never allow personal bias to influence her rulings.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON  Republican senators sparred with Judge Sonia Sotomayor on Tuesday over racial bias, judicial activism and temperament as she presented herself as a reliable follower of precedent rather than a jurist shaped by gender and ethnicity, as some of her past speeches suggested.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker and Neil A. Lewis
